content:
ControlType Class

Definition

Identifies the type of a user interface (UI) control.

In this Article

public class ControlType : System.Windows.Automation.AutomationIdentifier
Inheritance
Object
System.Windows.Automation.AutomationIdentifier
ControlType

Inherited Members

Equals(Object,Object)
GetType()
MemberwiseClone()
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)
ToString()
CompareTo(Object)
Equals(Object)
GetHashCode()
Id
ProgrammaticName

Remarks

ControlType inherits from AutomationIdentifier and is used to identify the type of a control represented by an AutomationElement. The control type is determined by the developer of the UI Automation provider.

This class contains static fields, which are themselves ControlType objects, to identify the standard types of controls. There is also a Custom type for controls that do not match one of the defined types.

The only case where a control's control type might change at run time is where the control supports MultipleViewPattern. An example is the Win32 list view, which can be a DataGrid or List, depending on the current view.

Control types do not have a one-to-one equivalence to control patterns. A control can be of only one type, but it may support multiple patterns or no patterns at all, depending on its specific functionality.

For detailed information on the various control types, see UI Automation Control Types.

Fields

Button

Identifies a button control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Button;

Remarks

Buttons perform a single action when clicked.

A button can be used as a standalone control or as a subcontrol in another control type. For example, the drop-down arrow in a combo box control is a button. When used as a subcontrol, a button is in the control view of the UI Automation tree (not in the content view).

Calendar

Identifies a calendar control, such as a date-picker.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Calendar;

CheckBox

Identifies a check box control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType CheckBox;

Remarks

A check box can be used as a standalone control or as a subcontrol in another control type. For example, a check box at the beginning of a row in a grid control that is used to select the row (used to manipulate the content) appears in the control view but not in the content view. However, a labeled checkbox in a form that represents data is in the content and control views.

ComboBox

Identifies a combo box control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType ComboBox;

Remarks

There are two variations of combo box controls. A simple combo box presents a list that a user can select from. An editable combo box presents a list of choices and also has an editable text area where a user can type in a choice instead of being limited to selecting from the choices in the list.

Custom

Identifies a control that is not one of the defined control types.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Custom;

Remarks

The Custom control type indicates a control that is not identified as one of the predefined control types (such as ControlType or ControlType).

Control developers should check the other control types before designating their control as a Custom control type to be sure that their control does not provide the same functionality as one of the defined control types.

A Custom control type requires extra work for the provider to implement UI Automation. Also, UI Automation client products will not be able to anticipate the control structure, keyboard interaction, and possible control patterns based on the control type of the control.

DataGrid

Identifies a data grid control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType DataGrid;

Remarks

When the cells contain only text, the control type should be ControlType.

DataItem

Identifies a data item control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType DataItem;

Remarks

A DataItem is a complex item that can contain many other controls.

Document

Identifies a document control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Document;

Remarks

A document contains text content of more than one line.

Edit

Identifies an edit control, such as a text box.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Edit;

Remarks

An Edit control can be used as a standalone control or as a subcontrol in another control type. For example, the area where a user can type in a value in a combo box control is an Edit control, and in this case the control is not part of the content view.

Edit controls can also represent controls that contain passwords. The IsPassword property enables products such as screen readers to know whether to reveal the contents.

Group

Identifies a group control, which acts as a container for other controls.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Group;

Remarks

A group is a container control that contains different control types and is used to logically associate those controls.

Header

Identifies a header control, which is a container for the labels of rows and columns of information.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Header;

HeaderItem

Identifies a header item, which is the label for a row or column of information.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType HeaderItem;

Hyperlink

Identifies a hyperlink control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Hyperlink;

Remarks

A hyperlink control navigates to a specified URL when a user clicks on the control.

Image

Identifies an image control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Image;

Remarks

An Image control type can be used as a standalone control or as a subcontrol in another control type. For example, a button can use an image rather than text to indicate its functionality to the user.

When used only for decorative purposes, an image appears in the control view of the UI Automation tree (not in the content view).

List

Identifies a list control, such as a list box.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType List;

Remarks

A List is a control type that contains ControlType and (perhaps) ControlType control types.

A List control can be used as a standalone control or as a subcontrol in another control type. For example, a combo box has a List control that contains choices that appear when the drop-down button is clicked. When used as a subcontrol, a List is only in the control view of the UI Automation tree (not in content view).

When used as a subcontrol, a List does not have a Name property assigned.

A List can contain ControlType controls.

ListItem

Identifies a list item control, which is a child item of a list control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType ListItem;

Remarks

A ControlType can also be a child of a list control.

Menu

Identifies a menu control, such as a top-level menu in an application window.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Menu;

Remarks

A menu is a container for a collection of menu items; for instance, the control that appears beneath File when you click on it and that contains New, Open, and so on.

MenuBar

Identifies a menu bar control, which generally contains a set of top-level menus.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType MenuBar;

Remarks

A MenuBar control type represents the container for the set of top-level menus of an application.

MenuItem

Identifies a menu item control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType MenuItem;

Remarks

A MenuItem is a child of a ControlType or ControlType control.

Pane

Identifies a pane control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Pane;

Remarks

A Pane is used to visually separate content within a ControlType. The user typically navigates between panes by pressing TAB, F6, or CTRL+TAB, depending on the context.

ProgressBar

Identifies a progress bar control, which visually indicates the progress of a lengthy operation.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType ProgressBar;

RadioButton

Identifies a radio button control, which is a selection mechanism allowing exactly one selected item in a group.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType RadioButton;

ScrollBar

Identifies a scroll bar control, such as a scroll bar in an application window.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType ScrollBar;

Remarks

A ScrollBar control type contains a set of buttons and a thumb control that enable a user using a mouse to scroll the contents of a window or item container.

Use the AutomationId property to differentiate between the Button elements that correspond to the large-increment, large-decrement, small-increment, and small-decrement buttons.

Separator

Identifies a separator, which creates a visual division in controls like menus and toolbars.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Separator;

Slider

Identifies a slider control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Slider;

Remarks

A Slider control type consists of a set of buttons associated with an ControlType control that enable a user to select from a set of items or set a numerical value from within a range.

Spinner

Identifies a spinner control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Spinner;

Remarks

A Spinner control type consists of a set of buttons that enable a user to select from a set of items or set a numerical value from within a range.

SplitButton

Identifies a split button, which is a button that performs a default action and can also expand to a list of other possible actions.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType SplitButton;

StatusBar

Identifies a status bar control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType StatusBar;

Remarks

StatusBar control types are generally subcontrols of ControlType control type UI Automation elements.

Tab

Identifies a tab control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Tab;

Remarks

A Tab is a control type that contains at least one ControlType child control.

TabItem

Identifies a tab item control, which represents a page of a tab control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType TabItem;

Table

Identifies a table.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Table;

Remarks

A Table control type is similar to a ControlType but contains only text. Tables can also contain ControlType control types.

Text

Identifies an edit control, such as a text box or rich text box.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Text;

Remarks

A Text control can be used as a standalone control, such as an ControlType control, or as a subcomponent, such as the area of a ControlType where a user can type in a value.

Thumb

Identifies the control in a scrollbar that can be dragged to a different position.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Thumb;

Remarks

A Thumb control is used as a subcontrol in a ControlType control type. As a subcontrol, a Thumb does not have a NameProperty.

TitleBar

Identifies the caption bar on a window.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType TitleBar;

ToolBar

Identifies a toolbar, such as the control that contains a set of command buttons in an application window.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType ToolBar;

ToolTip

Identifies a tooltip control, an informational window that appears as a result of moving the pointer over a control or sometimes when tabbing to a control using the keyboard.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType ToolTip;

Tree

Identifies a tree control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Tree;

Remarks

A Tree control type is a container for a hierarchical arrangement of ControlType or ControlType control types.

Each node of a tree can contain other nodes. A node that contains child nodes can be displayed as expanded or collapsed.

TreeItem

Identifies a node in a TreeItem control.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType TreeItem;

Remarks

A TreeItem control type can be used only as a subcontrol of a ControlType control.

Window

Identifies a window frame, which contains child objects.

public static readonly System.Windows.Automation.ControlType Window;

Remarks

Controls of this type always support WindowPattern.

Properties

LocalizedControlType

Gets a description of the control type.

public string LocalizedControlType { get; }
Value
String

A localized description of the control type, such as "button".

Methods

GetNeverSupportedPatterns()

Retrieves the pattern identifiers that are not supported by the control type.

public System.Windows.Automation.AutomationPattern[] GetNeverSupportedPatterns ();
Returns
AutomationPattern[]

An array of UI Automation pattern identifiers.

Remarks

This method is useful for UI Automation clients such as test frameworks for a provider implementation that need to find all control patterns that are not permitted on this control type.

GetRequiredPatternSets()

Retrieves an array of sets of required patterns.

public System.Windows.Automation.AutomationPattern[][] GetRequiredPatternSets ();
Returns
AutomationPattern[][]

An array of sets of required patterns.

Remarks

Each element of the array contains an array of patterns, and each element that has this control type must support at least one of these arrays.

This method is useful for UI Automation clients that need to find all possible patterns, such as testing frameworks for a provider implementation.

GetRequiredProperties()

Retrieves an array of the required property identifiers (IDs) for this control type.

public System.Windows.Automation.AutomationProperty[] GetRequiredProperties ();
Returns
AutomationProperty[]

An array of property IDs.

Remarks

This method is useful for UI Automation clients that need to find all possible properties, such as testing frameworks for a provider implementation.

LookupById(Int32)

Retrieves a ControlType that encapsulates a specified numerical identifier.

public static System.Windows.Automation.ControlType LookupById (int id);
id
Int32

Identifier of the control type.

Returns
ControlType

To be added.

Remarks

Normally the type of a control is identified by a ControlType object. This method enables you to construct such an object when only the numerical identifier is known.
